items.author: Michael Nikitochkin

In a single afternoon, I transformed my test suite from a 4-minute ordeal into a 3-second sprint by replacing expensive database with lightning-fast . This 98.8% performance improvement didn't just make developers happier‚Äîit fundamentally changed how I approach testing.

The Problem: When Tests Become a Bottleneck

The test suite was destroying developer productivity. Every pull request meant waiting, every bug fix meant coffee breaks. With truncation-based test isolation, the team was hemorrhaging time:

The Root Cause: Truncation Hell

The culprit was my test isolation strategy: . Before each test, I was:

  1. Dropping and recreating data across 20+ tables
  2. Performing expensive I/O operations that scaled with data size

Each test was paying a tax just to clean up after itself. With 447 tests, that's over 3 minutes of pure overhead.

The Solution: Transaction Rollback Strategy

Instead of physically deleting data and resetting sequences, I could simply wrap each test in a database transaction and . transactions are designed for exactly this‚Äîatomic operations that can be discarded instantly.

  2. Only test data is transactional - All changes disappear instantly

Before (Truncation Hell):

items.title: Crystal Minitest and the Shutdown Order Problem
items.author: Michael Nikitochkin
items.content:
: Optimizing setup by moving initialization from to module-level broke logging: creates resources early, and they're cleaned up before tests run (which happens in ). Solution: use for tests instead.

Story: The Optimization and Discovery

When setting up a application to work with , I moved all initialization instructions to hooks:

After tests were working reliably, I optimized: why run this repetitive setup for every test? If I moved it to module-level initialization, it would run once when test file loads:

Tests passed initially. But when I ran with to enable verbose output, something broke:

1 crystal run /users_test.cr

Channel::ClosedError: Channel is closed
    /usr/share/crystal/src/channel.cr:142:8 in 'send'
    /usr/share/crystal/src/log/dispatch.cr:55:7 in 'dispatch'

The logging channel was closed. I reverted to as a workaround, but I needed to understand: Why does setup runs matter more than it runs?

Investigation: The Key Discovery

Why Minitest Is Different

doesn't run tests during normal program execution. Instead:

This creates a timing problem. With module-level setup:

  1. initialize a Log instance with on booting
  2. spawns a background fiber with a channel
  3. Main program completes ‚Üí runtime cleanup begins
  4. Channel may be closed by garbage collection (this is where my assumption lies)
  5. fires ‚Üí runs tests
  6. Tests call ‚Üí channel already closed ‚Üí

With , setup happens inside , so the instance is created during shutdown, not during normal execution.

How Works

During shutdown, garbage collection calls , which closes the channel. But hooks run some cleanup, creating the race condition.

The issue isn't optimization itself‚Äîit's that isn't suitable for code that runs before . The solution is to use a dispatcher without background resources for tests:

For tests with module-level init, is ideal.

The optimization itself was sound‚Äîmodule-level initialization faster. The issue was incompatibility with in a shutdown context.

More broadly, any code that relies on objects with finalize methods could be affected by garbage collection events and timing‚Äîbackground resources created during normal execution may be cleaned up before tests run.

The fix is simple (one configuration change) but reveals a broader principle:

Test infrastructure must account for shutdown order and resource cleanup timing, regardless of framework. Some libraries use handlers for cleanup in multi-threaded applications, and when tests run after these handlers, any finalized objects (channels, connections, files, caches) become inaccessible.
